quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Mary and Singer
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, mary, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: On what date do Roman Catholic, Anglican and Eastern Orthodox churches observe the day of St. Mary Magdalene?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: July 22

questions.question: A popular 1960s group, who scored big with their Smash Hit Mony, Mony .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tommy James and the Shondelles

questions.question: Marie Fredriksson, lead singer of the Swedish pop group Roxette, was diagnosed with what dangerous illness in 2002?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brain cancer

questions.question: In which of these movies did actress Mary Kate Olsen star without her twin Ashley Olsen?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Factory Girl

questions.question: Who sponsored Christopher Columbus voyage during which he discovered America?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Queen Isabella I of Spain

questions.question: Queen Mary I of England was also known as Bloody Mary because she persecuted which social group?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Protestants

questions.question: What does the J stand for in the name of the Grammy Award-winning singer Mary J. Blige?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jane

questions.question: Which English king, who reigned from 1714 to 1727, could not speak English?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: King George I

questions.question: Which famous King of France, who reigned in the 17th century, is widely-known as The Sun King?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Louis XIV

questions.question: Which of these world-famous tennis players became the Wimbledon 2004 Champion?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maria Sharapova

questions.question: Which of these musicians didnt release a song named Maria in 1999?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Red Hot Chili Peppers

questions.question: Which actress played the role of Mary in the 1998 movie Theres Something About Mary?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cameron Diaz

questions.question: In the 19th century, English writer Mary Shelley wrote which famous gothic novel?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Frankenstein

questions.question: This singer and entertainer is well known for his hit song, Love Me Tonight.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tom Jones

questions.question: In 1903 and 1911, Polish-French scientist Marie Curie received which Nobel Prizes?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: In Physics and in Chemistry

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Pirates and Queen
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, piracy. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: There were women pirates.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In the past, pirates with a commission or letter of Marque to legally attack enemy ships were called freebooters.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Name the King of England who was married six times and established the Church of England in 1534.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: King Henry VIII

questions.question: Two of the hotbeds for pirate activity were the islands of Tortuga and Port Royal.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which Queen of France was guillotined in 1793 during the French Revolution of 1789–1799?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marie Antoinette

questions.question: Black Bart was the most successful pirate in the Golden Age of Piracy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Born in 1683, King Philip V was the first Spanish king of which royal dynasty?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bourbon

questions.question: In the 21st century, pirates still roam the seas and account for billions of dollars in loss each year.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Who was the father of Charles the Great, King of the Franks of the Carolingian dynasty?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: King Pippin the Short

questions.question: Three of these names refer to one and the same queen. Which is the odd one?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary, Queen of Scots

questions.question: Pirates who operated out of the West Indies were known as Buccaneers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which of these monarchs is not correctly matched to the country he ruled?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: King Harald V  - Denmark

questions.question: The famed piracy in the Caribbean started around the first half of 1500s.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Pirate society was run as a democracy in which votes were taken.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which queen founded a union of the Scandinavian countries in 1397 and ruled Norway, Denmark and Sweden?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Margaret I

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Tea and Inventor
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, invention. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This man invented the compact disc in 1965.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Russell

questions.question: Among his many inventions were eyeglasses for near and far-sightedness.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johannes Kepler

questions.question: Who was U.S. President during the terrorist attacks of September 11th, 2001?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Walker Bush

questions.question: He invented the first medical thermometer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sir Thomas Allbutt

questions.question: This Hungarian journalist invented and patented the ball point pen.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Laszlo Biro

questions.question: This pharmacist was the inventor of Coca Cola.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Doctor John Pemberton

questions.question: What U.S. President annexed Texas in 1845?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Tyler

questions.question: He was a salesman of tea, coffee, and sugar.  Later, in 1876  he invented the gas motor engine.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nicolaus August Otto

questions.question: This woman invented a method for cleaning and curing the Indian corn crops.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sybilla Masters

questions.question: The pirate term cackle fruit referred to bananas.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: He invented the air conditioner in 1902.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Willis Haviland Carrier

questions.question: Who was President during the Iran hostage crisis (1979)?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Earl (Jimmy) Carter

questions.question: Pirate Blackbeard had the longest reign of terror among pirates.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This tea and coffee shop merchant from New York is the inventor of tea bags. He started sending samples of tea in small silk bags, but people preferred to dip the tea in the hot water along with the bag.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Sullivan

questions.question: This Canadian doctor is widely credited for the invention of the first gas mask, in response to German use of poison gas during World War I.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cluny MacPherson

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Christopher Columbus and Voyage
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, sail. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who was U.S. President during the fall of the Berlin Wall, and witnessed the end of the Cold War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Herbert Walker Bush

questions.question: The Leigh Light named after its inventor Humphry de Verde Leigh, is a type of what British military device from World War II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anti-submarine device

questions.question: In 1492, Christopher Columbus set sail on his first voyage in search of the Indies with which three ships?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Santa Maria, Pinta and Niña

questions.question: What Chief Executive was a Presidents grandson?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benjamin Harrison

questions.question: The diesel engine is named after Rudolf Diesel, an inventor of what nationality?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: German

questions.question: Where did Christopher Columbus die on May 20, 1506?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Valladolid, Spain

questions.question: According to the contract between Columbus and the Spanish monarchs, what would happen if he discovered new mainland?

options.text: Columbus would be proclaimed Admiral of the Ocean Sea.
Columbus would marry the heir to the Spanish throne.
Columbus would have the sole right to sell slaves from the new lands.
Columbus would be appointed Governor of Andalusia.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Columbus would be proclaimed Admiral of the Ocean Sea.

questions.question: What name did Christopher Columbus give to Cuba, when he landed there on April 30, 1494?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Juana

questions.question: How was Christopher Columbus corpse treated immediately after his death?

options.text: The head was removed from the body.
The flesh was removed from the bones.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The flesh was removed from the bones.

questions.question: In 2002, Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez changed the name of Columbus Day with what new name of the holiday?

options.text: The Day of the New World

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Day of Indigenous Resistance

questions.question: On his fourth voyage, Christopher Columbus was accompanied by which members of his family, called Bartolomeo and Fernando?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: His brother and his son

questions.question: Who was the first European to reach the American shores several centuries before the first voyage of Columbus?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leifr Eiríksson

questions.question: What U.S. President faced impeachment in 1868 for steadfastly opposing Radicals in Congress?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andrew Johnson

questions.question: Which previously-unknown plant was brought to Europe by Christopher Columbus in 1493?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tobacco

questions.question: Columbus Day, a holiday first observed by the Tammany Society, is officially celebrated in the USA in which month?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: October

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Woman and Method
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, zeppelin, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who was the first American female writer whose works were published?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anne Bradstreet

questions.question: The zeppelin took the name of German nobleman Ferdinand von Zeppelin who bore what title?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Count

questions.question: George Washington Gale Ferris, Jr. constructed the modern version of the Ferris wheel in 1893 for what major world exposition?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Worlds Columbian Exposition, Chicago, Illinois 1893

questions.question: The Morse code, named after one of its inventors, Samuel Morse, is a method for transmitting information using short and long marks - dots and dashes. In the international Morse code standards, the pause between two words equals what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 5 dots

questions.question: Who established the first charitable organization for women in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anne Parrish

questions.question: The Braille system, devised in 1821 by Louis Braille, is a method of reading and writing used by blind people. In the Braille alphabet each letter is represented by the so-called Braille cell, which is a grid of up to how many raised dots?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 6

questions.question: Who was the first woman to receive a patent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary Kies

questions.question: The meringue dessert Pavlova is named after the famous Russian Anna Pavlova. What was Pavlovas occupation?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ballet dancer

questions.question: What woman appeared in the first ballet presented in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Suzanne Vaillande

questions.question: The popular mechanical puzzle Rubiks Cube, designed by Hungarian sculptor and professor of architecture Ernő Rubik, comes in four different versions depending on the number of its squares. In the standard 3×3×3 version what is the total number of visible cube faces?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 54

questions.question: Which of these popular food names derives from its inventors title?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sandwich

questions.question: The Richter magnitude scale, named after American seismologist Charles Richter, is used to quantify the size of an earthquake. What is the highest number in the scale?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 10

questions.question: Who was the first American woman to run a print shop?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anne Catherine Hoof Green

questions.question: Who was the first professional woman artist in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henrietta Johnston

questions.question: Who was the first female child born to English parents in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Virginia Dare

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Epitaph and Plane
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, stars. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This  blue-eyed soul  singer has the following epitaph:
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bobby Hatfield

questions.question: This 7-year-old pilot trainee was attempting to become the youngest person to fly a plane across the United States when her plane went down.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jessica Dubroff

questions.question: What great Americans self written epitaph reads:

options.text: thor Of The Declaration Of American Independence
d The Father Of The University Of Virginia

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jefferson

questions.question: Joan of Arc was only 16 when she died.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What sports legend has as his epitaph:
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roger Maris

questions.question: On whose tombstone would you find this quotation taken from one of his most famous poems?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Edgar Allan Poe

questions.question: Who was the first native-born American woman to be canonized by the Roman Catholic Church?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elizabeth Ann Seton

questions.question: This child actor born in 1958 was one of the stars of the television show Family Affair.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anissa Jones

questions.question: Known as  The Man of a 1,000 Voices , who has as his epitaph THATS ALL FOLKS! ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mel Blanc

questions.question: This promising new star died in 1988. She starred in several television shows and movies in her short career. She was the voice of Ducky in The Land Before Time and the voice of Anne-Marie in All Dogs Go to Heaven. She also played Michael (Brody) and Carlas daughter in Jaws: The Revenge.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Judith Barsi

questions.question: Lady Jane Grey died in 1554 from typhoid fever.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Who was the first African American woman to become a physician in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rebecca Crumpler

questions.question: This Russian Emperor died at the age of 14 ending the direct male descendants of the Romanov Dynasty.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Peter II

questions.question: On March 9, 1982 his friend led his funeral procession riding a motorcycle and  wearing a leather jacket and jeans.  Two days later at his memorial service this same friend played the Ventures song  2,000 Pound Bee  before 1,000 mourners at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.  Whose epitaph reads  I May Be Gone But Rock And Roll Lives On?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Belushi

questions.question: Who was the first female doctor in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elizabeth Blackwell
